message.content:
cs.GT, cs.NI, cs.IT, cs.DS, cs.AI. 

The paper deals with the design of truthful auctions for secondary spectrum usage in wireless networks, which involves allocation of communication requests to available channels subject to interference and noise. This problem is related to game theory (cs.GT) as it involves designing mechanisms that incentivize bidders to reveal their true valuations. It also involves modeling interference using conflict graphs, which is related to network science (cs.NI) and graph theory (cs.DS). The paper also uses LP-rounding and convex rounding frameworks, which are techniques commonly used in optimization (cs.IT) and approximation algorithms (cs.DS). Finally, the paper discusses the use of randomized meta-rounding and deterministically truthful mechanisms, which are related to randomized algorithms (cs.AI) and mechanism design (cs.GT).
